Abstract: A method of beam energy spread and synchrotron tune measurements based on the analysis of transverse decoherence\recoherence signal of kicked beam is presented. As an illustration the beam energy spread was extracted for the SLS storage ring.

Authors: Wallen E.
Title: Insertion devices for the MAX IV 3 GeV ring
Affiliations: MAX-Lab., Lund, Sweden
Authors with affiliations: Wallen, E., MAX-Lab., Lund, Sweden
Abstract: The MAX IV light source, presently under construction at MAX-lab in Lund, Sweden, will consist of two separate storage rings and a linac-driven short-pulse facility. The two storage rings are operated at different energies, 3 GeV and 1.5 GeV, to provide synchrotron radiation of high brightness over a broad spectral range. The 3 GeV linac serves as a full-energy injector for the storage rings as well as the driver of the short-pulse facility delivering intense x-ray pulses. The paper describes a selection of possible insertion devices to be installed at the MAX IV 3 GeV ring and the expected heat loads produced by the insertion devices.
Index Keywords: Broad spectral; High brightness; Insertion device; Short-pulse; X ray pulse; Light sources; Linear accelerators; Storage rings

Title: ASTRID2 - The new low-emittance light source in Denmark

Abstract: A new low-energy synchrotron radiation light source is presently being built at Aarhus University. The storage ring will circulate a 580 MeV electron beam with an emittance of 10 nm. Due to the moderate lifetime of a few hours, the machine will be operated in top-up mode at 200 mA with injection from the present ASTRID storage ring. In the present contribution, we will describe aspects of the lattice, the injection and the expected performance of the machine.

Title: Superconducting magnets for the nica facility at JINR: Status of the design and construction plans
Affiliations: Laboratory of High Energy Physics, Joint Institute for Nuclear Research, 141980, Dubna, Russian Federation
Authors with affiliations: Kovalenko, A.D., Laboratory of High Energy Physics, Joint Institute for Nuclear Research, 141980, Dubna, Russian Federation; Agapov, N.N., Laboratory of High Energy Physics, Joint Institute for Nuclear Research, 141980, Dubna, Russian Federation; Kekelidze, V.D., Laboratory of High Energy Physics, Joint Institute for Nuclear Research, 141980, Dubna, Russian Federation; Khodzhibagiyan, H.G., Laboratory of High Energy Physics, Joint Institute for Nuclear Research, 141980, Dubna, Russian Federation; Meshkov, I.N., Laboratory of High Energy Physics, Joint Institute for Nuclear Research, 141980, Dubna, Russian Federation; Mikhaylov, V.A., Laboratory of High Energy Physics, Joint Institute for Nuclear Research, 141980, Dubna, Russian Federation; Petrov, V.A., Laboratory of High Energy Physics, Joint Institute for Nuclear Research, 141980, Dubna, Russian Federation; Sissakian, A.N., Laboratory of High Energy Physics, Joint Institute for Nuclear Research, 141980, Dubna, Russian Federation; Sorin, A.S., Laboratory of High Energy Physics, Joint Institute for Nuclear Research, 141980, Dubna, Russian Federation; Trubnikov, G.V., Laboratory of High Energy Physics, Joint Institute for Nuclear Research, 141980, Dubna, Russian Federation
Abstract: NICA (Nuclotron-based Ion Collider Facility) is the new accelerator complex being under design and construction at JINR since 2007. The facility is aimed to provide collider experiments with heavy ions up to uranium (gold at the beginning stage) with a centre of mass energy up to 11 GeV/u and an average luminosity up to 1027 cm-2 s-1. The collisions of polarized deuterons and protons are foreseen also. The accelerator complex includes two injector linacs, a superconducting booster synchrotron, the modernized Nuclotron - 6 GeV/u superconducting synchrotron and a collider consisting of two storage rings. Different modifications of magnets based on a hollow composite NbTi cable at 4.5 K are considered for the NICA booster and collider rings. The twin-aperture collider structural dipole and quadrupole magnet units consist of two vertically assembled cold masses placed inside a common cryostat are fixed as basis for the collider lattice structure. Both 2 T window-frame and 4 T Cosine(θ) dipoles options were considered. The 2 T curved dipole option was recommended for the collider ring circumference longer then 200 m (external option). Design and manufacturing of the first model magnets is in progress. Substantial efforts were devoted rearrangement of the facility for assembling and full-scale tests of different superconducting magnets at the Laboratory. Reaching of the planned production capacity of 2-2.5 magnet units per week will make it possible to complete the NICA magnets manufacturing and tests within three years.
Index Keywords: Accelerator complex; Booster-synchrotrons; Centre-of-mass energies; Design and construction; Lattice structures; Polarized deuterons; Production capacity; Quadrupole magnets; Design; Deuterium; Magnets; Manufacture; Particle accelerators; Superconducting magnets; Superconductivity; High energy physics

Authors: Leemann S.C., Ahlbäck J., Andersson Å., Eriksson M., Johansson M., Lindgren L.-J., Sjöström M., Wallen E.
Title: Status of the MAX IV storage rings
Affiliations: MAX-Lab., Lund University, SE-22100 Lund, Sweden
Authors with affiliations: Leemann, S.C., MAX-Lab., Lund University, SE-22100 Lund, Sweden; Ahlbäck, J., MAX-Lab., Lund University, SE-22100 Lund, Sweden; Andersson, Å., MAX-Lab., Lund University, SE-22100 Lund, Sweden; Eriksson, M., MAX-Lab., Lund University, SE-22100 Lund, Sweden; Johansson, M., MAX-Lab., Lund University, SE-22100 Lund, Sweden; Lindgren, L.-J., MAX-Lab., Lund University, SE-22100 Lund, Sweden; Sjöström, M., MAX-Lab., Lund University, SE-22100 Lund, Sweden; Wallen, E., MAX-Lab., Lund University, SE-22100 Lund, Sweden
Abstract: In 2009 the MAX IV facility was granted funding by Swedish authorities. Construction of the facility will begin this summer and user operation is expected by 2015. MAX IV will consist of a 3.4 GeV linac as a driver for a short-pulse radiation facility (with planned upgrade to a seeded/cascaded FEL) as well as an injector for two storage rings at different energies serving user communities in separate spectral ranges. Thanks to a novel compact multibend-achromat design, the 3 GeV ring will deliver a 500 mA electron beam with a horizontal emittance below 0.3 nm rad to x-ray insertion devices located in 19 dispersion-free 5 m straight sections. When the 3 GeV ring goes into operation in 2015 it is expected to become the highest electron-brightness storage ring light source worldwide. The 1.5 GeV ring will serve as a replacement for both present-day MAX II and MAX III storage rings. Its below 6 nmrad horizontal emittance electron beam will be delivered to IR and UV insertion devices in twelve 3.5 m straight sections. We report on design progress for the two new storage rings of the MAX IV facility.
Index Keywords: Design progress; Emittances; Insertion device; Short-pulse radiation; Spectral range; Swedishs; User communities; Electron beams; Light sources; Storage rings

Authors: Hutter M., David Remy C., Siegwart R.
Title: Design of an articulated robotic leg with nonlinear series elastic actuation
Source title: Mobile Robotics: Solutions and Challenges - Proceedings of the 12th International Conference on Climbing and Walking Robots and the Support Technologies for Mobile Machines, CLAWAR 2009
Affiliations: Autonomous Systems Lab, CLA E11.2, ETH Zurich, Tannenstrasse 3, 8092 Zurich, Switzerland
Authors with affiliations: Hutter, M., Autonomous Systems Lab, CLA E11.2, ETH Zurich, Tannenstrasse 3, 8092 Zurich, Switzerland; David Remy, C., Autonomous Systems Lab, CLA E11.2, ETH Zurich, Tannenstrasse 3, 8092 Zurich, Switzerland; Siegwart, R., Autonomous Systems Lab, CLA E11.2, ETH Zurich, Tannenstrasse 3, 8092 Zurich, Switzerland
Abstract: An articulated leg for the use in a running robot is presented. It is driven by series elastic actuation with a highly compliant spring at the knee joint to exploit periodic energy storage and passively support a running motion. The spring is connected with the knee motor by a cable pulley system, which allows the advantageous placement of the motor in the hip joint and enables us to use a compression spring instead of a heavier torsional element. Additionally, the pulley system creates a nonlinear spring characteristic at joint level which can be shaped by altering the cable tension. This nonlinearity and the inertial effects associated with it substantially increase the effective damping in the unloaded leg and allow precise foot-placement during the flight phase. Still, damping of the loaded leg during stance phase is kept minimal for highly efficient energy recovery.
Index Keywords: Compression springs; Effective damping; Energy recovery; Inertial effect; Non-linear springs; Periodic energy; Running robots; Series elastic actuations; Cables; Joints (anatomy); Mobile robots; Pulleys; Robotics

Authors: Domínguez-Delgado C.L., Rodríguez-Cruz I.M., López-Cervantes M.
Title: The skin: A Valuable Route for Administration of Drugs
Source title: Current Technologies to Increase the Transdermal Delivery of Drugs
Affiliations: Departamento de Ingeniería y Tecnología, Sección de Tecnología Farmacéutica, Facultad de, Universidad Nacional Autónoma de México, Estado de México, 54704, Mexico; Comisión Federal de Protección contra Riesgos Sanitarios, Gerencia de Medicamentos, Monterrey No. 33, Col. Roma, Delegacion Cuauhtemoc, C.P. 06700, México, D.F., Mexico
Authors with affiliations: Domínguez-Delgado, C.L., Departamento de Ingeniería y Tecnología, Sección de Tecnología Farmacéutica, Facultad de, Universidad Nacional Autónoma de México, Estado de México, 54704, Mexico; Rodríguez-Cruz, I.M., Departamento de Ingeniería y Tecnología, Sección de Tecnología Farmacéutica, Facultad de, Universidad Nacional Autónoma de México, Estado de México, 54704, Mexico; López-Cervantes, M., Departamento de Ingeniería y Tecnología, Sección de Tecnología Farmacéutica, Facultad de, Universidad Nacional Autónoma de México, Estado de México, 54704, Mexico, Comisión Federal de Protección contra Riesgos Sanitarios, Gerencia de Medicamentos, Monterrey No. 33, Col. Roma, Delegacion Cuauhtemoc, C.P. 06700, México, D.F., Mexico
Abstract: The skin is the largest organ of the body and its main function is to protect the organism against undesirable effects of the environment. The skin is composed of three different layers: epidermis, dermis and hypodermis. The epidermis contains the stratum corneum, the uppermost layer of the epidermis, that acts as the barrier function of the skin due to its very high density and its low hydration. The dermis is an extensive vascular network providing skin nutrition, repair, thermal regulation and immune response. The hypodermis acts as a heat insulator, a shock absorber, and an energy storage region. There are also several appendages in the skin: hair follicles, sebaceous, sweat glands and nails. The skin properties play an important role to allow penetration of topically applied drugs or substances into the skin. Drug permeation through the skin include the diffusion through the intact epidermis and the skin appendages. In this chapter we reviewed structure, immunological and electrical properties, penetration routes of drugs throughout skin, types of skin and the most common skin disorders that affect humans. © 2010 Bentham Science Publishers Ltd. All rights reserved.

Authors: Machado C.X., Ketzer J.M.M., Rockett G.C., Centeno C.I.
Title: Brazilian Atlas on CO2 Capture, transport and geological storage: Developing methodology
Source title: Brazilian Petroleum, Gas and Biofuels Institute [IBP] Rio Oil and Gas Conference (Rio de Janeiro, Brazil, 9/13-16/2010) Techn
Affiliations: Pontificia Univ. Rio Grande, Brazil
Authors with affiliations: Machado, C.X., Pontificia Univ. Rio Grande, Brazil; Ketzer, J.M.M., Pontificia Univ. Rio Grande, Brazil; Rockett, G.C., Pontificia Univ. Rio Grande, Brazil; Centeno, C.I., Pontificia Univ. Rio Grande, Brazil
Abstract: The Brazilian Atlas on CO2 capture, transport and geological storage is a pioneering initiative in Brazil and has been prepared by the research program CARBMAP of the Brazilian Carbon Storage Research Center (CEPAC/PUCRS). As the example of the one being developed in South Africa and the ones already published for Australia, the U.S. and Canada, the publication will present the current status and future prospects of the country for CO2 capture, transport and geological storage (CCS) which could in the future benefit the oil and energy industry in the country, assisting the planning of CCS projects. The aim of this paper is to present the methodology to elaborate the Atlas. The relationship/intersection of data and information collected by CARBMAP regarding technical aspects of CCS projects such as data on CO2 stationary sources, suggested capture technology, identification of potential areas for geological storage in sedimentary basins, allows the development of a publication that can help to disseminate knowledge on CCS, extending it beyond the narrow scientific circles.

Authors: Cutic N., Eriksson M., Lindau F., Thorin S., Werin S.
Title: The MAX IV injector as A SOFT X-RAY FEL driver
Source title: FEL 2010 - 32nd International Free Electron Laser Conference
Affiliations: MAX-Lab., Lund University, Sweden
Authors with affiliations: Cutic, N., MAX-Lab., Lund University, Sweden; Eriksson, M., MAX-Lab., Lund University, Sweden; Lindau, F., MAX-Lab., Lund University, Sweden; Thorin, S., MAX-Lab., Lund University, Sweden; Werin, S., MAX-Lab., Lund University, Sweden
Abstract: The MAX IV facility [1] consisting of a 3 GeV ultra low emittance storage ring and a full energy linac injector is funded and under construction. The injector linac [2] is designed to not only perform storage ring injection but also drive a Short Pulse Facility generating spontaneous incoherent photon pulses in the keV range with pulse lengths below 100 fs in the first phase of the project. We here sketch a possible future development of the facility. This source will, with minor modifications, be able to drive a Free Electron Laser down into the soft X-ray region and with an extended energy a full X-ray FEL at 1-2 Å. The key feature of the system is the availability of a 3-3.5 GeV linac, a low emittance photo cathode RF-gun and two bunch compressors including sextupoles for linearization. By extracting pulses of 0.1-0.2 nC charge, normalized emittances below 1 mm mRad and peak currents above 3 kA can be achieved. Such pulses are very well suited for a FEL facility.
Index Keywords: Key feature; Low emittance; Peak currents; Photon pulse; Possible futures; Pulse length; Soft X-ray FEL; Soft X-ray regions; Free electron lasers; Linear accelerators; Storage rings; X rays; Pulse generators

Authors: Lorin C., Todesco E.
Title: Dipole retraining for 7 TEV
Source title: Proceedings of the Chamonix 2010 Workshop on LHC Performance
Affiliations: CERN, Geneva, Switzerland
Authors with affiliations: Lorin, C., CERN, Geneva, Switzerland; Todesco, E., CERN, Geneva, Switzerland
Abstract: We outline the present understanding of the retraining of the main dipoles in the LHC sector 5-6 during 2008 hardware commissioning. Even though part of the observed retraining can be explained through the test of individual magnets taken during the production, there is an additional unexplained detraining. The energy of 6.5 TeV seems clearly at hand with a very limited retraining. We present the best estimates of the training needed to reach the range 6.5-7 TeV, using different methods. We then analyse correlations between performance and production procedures and components: the present stage of analysis does not show any trace of correlations, but the analysis is not yet completed. There is also no indication of a correlation with the storage time.
Index Keywords: Best estimates; Present stage; Production procedure; Storage time; Tellurium compounds

Authors: Iakov E., Vlachos D., Toka A.
Title: Waste biomass supply chains for energy production: A hierarchical decision-making framework
Source title: Waste Management: Research Advances to Convert Waste to Wealth
Affiliations: Laboratory of Quantitative Analysis, Department of Mechanical Engineering, Aristotle University of Thessaloniki, Greece
Authors with affiliations: Iakov, E., Laboratory of Quantitative Analysis, Department of Mechanical Engineering, Aristotle University of Thessaloniki, Greece; Vlachos, D.; Toka, A.
Abstract: The development of renewable energy sources has clearly emerged as a meaningful intervention for enhancing the fragile global energy system with its limited fossil fuel resources as well as for reducing the numerous related environmental problems. In this framework, biomass utilization has proven to be a viable alternative for energy production even though its usage is still at its infancy on a global scale. Thus, a number of critical issues for all the involved stakeholders, such as potential investors, involved regulators and decision-makers, need to be addressed systemically. One of the first challenges that hinders the increased biomass utilization for energy production is the cost of its respective logistics operations. What differentiates biomass supply chains from traditional supply chains is the importance of factors such as biomass product quality as this is dictated by the relevant energy production technology, weather related variability, localized agricultural capacity and seasonality, and stochasticity of demand. In this chapter, we present a novel methodological framework for the design and evaluation of sustainable waste biomass supply chains, taking into account the collection, storage, and transport operations for supplying facilities with organic raw materials for energy production. First, the potential of waste biomass for energy production is presented, as well as the relevant regulatory incentives, the constraints and the critical issues that have to be tackled. Moreover, the generic system components of Biomass Supply Chains (BSCs) are described in conjunction with their relevant key variables and unique characteristics. Following that, we recognize the natural hierarchy of the decision-making process and propose an integrated methodological framework that spans all levels of the hierarchy. We then map the existing research efforts within the proposed framework in order to identify gaps and overlaps. We proceed with a taxonomy of the current state of the art research, based on the relevant modeling techniques in order to identify the limitations of the existing modeling efforts. We wrap-up by discussing our conclusions in the last section. © 2010 by Nova Science Publishers, Inc. All rights reserved.

Authors: Malik A.S., Al-Jabri H.N., Al-Farsi F.N., Al-Ma'mary T.S., Al-Khadhuri M.K.
Title: Technoeconomic study of wind energy potential and prospects in Oman
Source title: ASME International Mechanical Engineering Congress and Exposition, Proceedings (IMECE)
Affiliations: College of Engineering, Sultan Qaboos University, Al-Khod, Oman
Authors with affiliations: Malik, A.S., College of Engineering, Sultan Qaboos University, Al-Khod, Oman; Al-Jabri, H.N., College of Engineering, Sultan Qaboos University, Al-Khod, Oman; Al-Farsi, F.N., College of Engineering, Sultan Qaboos University, Al-Khod, Oman; Al-Ma'mary, T.S., College of Engineering, Sultan Qaboos University, Al-Khod, Oman; Al-Khadhuri, M.K., College of Engineering, Sultan Qaboos University, Al-Khod, Oman
Abstract: This paper reports the study that carried out to find the wind energy potential and prospects in Oman. The results presented here are for three different sites. The first site discussed is for remote non-grid application of wind energy, the second for grid application and the third for wind pump application. The economic comparison for non-grid power applications is made between diesel engine generating sets alone and wind-diesel hybrid system at the selected location. The economic cost of grid system extension is also estimated for comparison purposes. The results show that for non-grid application for the selected site the levelized cost of winddiesel system is 0.105 $/kWh comparing to 0.148 $/kWh for diesel system alone. For grid power application the study found that installing a 20 MW wind farm in Quiroon Hariti has a levelized cost of energy comparable to long-run marginal cost of open cycle gas turbines. For wind pump application the study found that the total annualized cost of installing wind pumps for irrigating a selected farm in Thumrait without and with one day water storage is $1, 368 and $2, 067 respectively. The total annualized cost of using a diesel pump for irrigating the same farm is $3, 523. Copyright © 2010 by ASME.
Index Keywords: Economic comparisons; Generating set; Grid applications; Levelized costs; Open cycle gas turbines; Power applications; Techno-economic studies; Wind-diesel systems; Climate change; Costs; Diesel engines; Electric utilities; Hybrid systems; Mechanical engineering; Pumps; Systems analysis; Thermodynamics; Wind power; Electric power transmission networks

Authors: Klaptocz A., Nicoud J.-D.
Title: Technology and fabrication of ultralight micro-aerial vehicles
Affiliations: Lab of Intelligent Systems, EPFL, Lausanne, Switzerland; Didel SA, Belmont, Switzerland
Authors with affiliations: Klaptocz, A., Lab of Intelligent Systems, EPFL, Lausanne, Switzerland; Nicoud, J.-D., Didel SA, Belmont, Switzerland
Abstract: Recent advances in micro-air vehicles have produced impressive results for platforms weighing below 50∈g. The lightest platforms to take flight with a minimum of functionality are below 0.5∈g, but researchers dream of flying at insect size. However, many difficulties occur when scaling down existing technologies. Aerodynamic laws equate to decreased efficiency at smaller sizes and hence more power per weight is required. Current energy storage technologies do not have the required capacity and powertrains are no longer efficient enough. Construction is difficult due to small size and low weight requirements. This chapter surveys the status of current technology and its prospects in miniaturization and shows several examples to illustrate the state of the art and the difficulties in reaching ever-smaller platform sizes. © 2010 Springer-Verlag Berlin Heidelberg.

Authors: Sørensen B.
Title: On the Road Performance Simulation of Battery, Hydrogen, and Hybrid Cars
Affiliations: Department of Environmental Social and Spatial Change, Roskilde University, Bld. 11.1, Universitetsvej 1, PO Box 260, DK-4000 Roskilde, Denmark
Authors with affiliations: Sørensen, B., Department of Environmental Social and Spatial Change, Roskilde University, Bld. 11.1, Universitetsvej 1, PO Box 260, DK-4000 Roskilde, Denmark
Abstract: This chapter presents the on road performance simulation of battery, hydrogen, and hybrid cars. In the case of fuel cell automobile simulation, a series connection is used to pass all the generated electricity through a traction battery rather than directly to the motor. The vehicle used is still the Volkswagen Lupo where the battery chosen is just small enough with a capacity of 1.25 MJ to perform only smoothing operations and not act like an independent power source. The lithium-ion traction battery weighs 6 kg, the motor/controller system 60 kg, and the 40 kW fuel cell system weighs 130 kg, which include hydrogen fuel onboard storage and handling, leading to a total mass of 961 kg. The performance is as good as that of the diesel Lupo and the average energy use of the fuel cell during the trip is 1.138 MJ/km, which is equivalent to 3.5 l of gasoline per 100 km. The electric vehicle used for the simulation of a battery vehicle has a range of 455 km, requiring 1,000 modules of a model lithium-ion battery, storing up to 250 MJ and weighing 1,134 kg, which is more than double the vehicle mass. The simulation finds that the best performance is ensured when the battery is never discharged below 40%. For the simulation of a hybrid vehicle, the smallest self-recharging hybrid vehicle is used, which in addition to a 20-kW fuel cell, must have a 15-MJ lithium-ion battery. The battery efficiency in this case is found to be over 90%, with the lowest values occurring during freeway accelerations. © 2010 Elsevier B.V. All rights reserved.

Authors: Steyn S.J.M., Van Vuuren P.A., Van Schoor G.
Title: Multivariable H∞ control for an active magnetic bearing flywheel system
Affiliations: North-West University, School of Electrical, Electronic and Computer Engineering, Potchefstroom, South Africa
Authors with affiliations: Steyn, S.J.M., North-West University, School of Electrical, Electronic and Computer Engineering, Potchefstroom, South Africa; Van Vuuren, P.A., North-West University, School of Electrical, Electronic and Computer Engineering, Potchefstroom, South Africa; Van Schoor, G., North-West University, School of Electrical, Electronic and Computer Engineering, Potchefstroom, South Africa
Abstract: A state-space model with uncertainties for an active magnetic bearing energy storage flywheel system (Fly-UPS) is developed. A multivariable robust H∞ controller for the Fly-UPS is then synthesised. Different weighting schemes are explained and used for H∞ controller synthesis. Furthermore, the additive uncertainties between the nominal simulation model and the physical model at varied rotational speeds are characterised. Stability robustness for additive uncertainties is verified via the gain/phase margin stability robustness criterion. The performance robustness (disturbance attenuation) is analysed by assessing model sensitivity with the ISO/CD 14839-3 sensitivity standard.
Author Keywords: Active magnetic bearing; H-infinity control; Multivariable control; Robust control
Index Keywords: Active Magnetic Bearing; Controller synthesis; Disturbance attenuation; Energy storage flywheel; H-infinity control; Multivariable control; Performance robustness; Stability robustness; Computer simulation; Flywheels; Robust control; System stability; Wheels; Magnetic amplifiers

Authors: Yildirim A., Doǧan S.
Title: Underground coal gasification and applicability to thrace basin lignite in Turkey
Source title: 27th Annual International Pittsburgh Coal Conference 2010, PCC 2010
Affiliations: Turkish Petroleum Company, Turkey
Authors with affiliations: Yildirim, A., Turkish Petroleum Company, Turkey; Doǧan, S., Turkish Petroleum Company, Turkey
Abstract: As it is known that, hydrocarbon reserves have been declined rapidly and with other problems for energy demand, there have been expanded and renewed interests in new alternative technologies in worldwide. Underground Coal Gasification (UCG) is the one of those technologies for new energy sources. UCG is a gasification process carried on low calorific value, non mined or no minable coal seams due to the geological conditions (high fracture frequencies, volcanic, complex storage/tectonic structures). UCG process converts coal in situ into product gas (syngas) by using oxygen/steam mixture (air, enriched air, oxygen/water and carbon dioxide/oxygen). Here the coal beds react as a chemical reactor, thus gasification process is maintained underground rather than conventional gasification methods. In this process; coal, steam and oxygen are brought together to the combustion temperature for coal by adjusting the amount of oxygen carefully, the coal is not completely burned but decomposed chemically. The process is a partial oxidation rather than combustion. The resulting mixture (carbon monoxide, hydrogen, carbon dioxide, methane) is UCG gas (syngas) can be used Integrated Gasification Combined Cycle (IGCC) configuration as a supplement and substitute fuel for electricity generation and chemical synthesis resulting in manufacturing of synthetic liquid fuel or chemicals by Fisher-Tropsch process. Turkish Petroleum Company (TPAO), has a vision being an energy company and taking in the commission to assess the low calorific value lignite reserves in Turkey by clean coal technologies under the roof of Ministry of Energy and Natural Resources (ETKB) conjunction with General Directorate of Mineral Research and Exploration (MTA), Turkish Coal Enterprises (TKI), Electric Power Resources Survey and Development Administration (EIEI), Electricity Generation CO. INC (EUAS), ETI MINE Works General Management (ETI Maden), Turkish Hard Coal Enterprises (TTK) and General Directorate of Mining Affairs (MİGM). In this review, geological, geophysical and chemical studies have been done on the lignite beds, which were determined during natural gas drilling in Thrace Basin in Turkey and their applicability is being discussed to UCG processes.
Author Keywords: Gasification; IGCC; UCG
Index Keywords: Alternative technologies; Clean coal technologies; Electric Power Resource; IGCC; Integrated gasification combined cycle; Mineral research and explorations; UCG; Underground coal gasification; Calorific value; Carbon dioxide; Carbon monoxide; Carbonization; Chemical reactors; Coal deposits; Electric generators; Energy management; Gasification; Industry; Lignite; Methane; Mineral resources; Natural resources exploration; Oil well drilling; Oxygen; Petroleum research; Proven reserves; Synthesis gas; Coal combustion

Authors: Łabojko G., Sobolewski A., Czepirski L.
Title: Preparation and characteristics of formed active carbons for natural gas storage
Source title: 27th Annual International Pittsburgh Coal Conference 2010, PCC 2010
Affiliations: Institute for Chemical Processing of Coal, Zamkowa street 1, 41-803 Zabrze, Poland; AGH - University of Science and Technology, Faculty of Fuels and Energy, al. Mickiewicza 30, 30-059 Cracow, Poland
Authors with affiliations: Łabojko, G., Institute for Chemical Processing of Coal, Zamkowa street 1, 41-803 Zabrze, Poland; Sobolewski, A., Institute for Chemical Processing of Coal, Zamkowa street 1, 41-803 Zabrze, Poland; Czepirski, L., AGH - University of Science and Technology, Faculty of Fuels and Energy, al. Mickiewicza 30, 30-059 Cracow, Poland
Abstract: Natural gas as an automotive fuel presents various advantages versus petrol and gasoline including reduced vehicle emissions, lower maintenance and savings in fuel costs. Main problem in using natural gas as fuel for vehicles is low volumetric energy density of methane at room temperature. Compressed Natural Gas (CNG) is a solution used worldwide (more than 4 millions vehicles), but heavy and expensive cylinders have to be used for its storage at pressures about 200 bar. Adsorbed Natural Gas (ANG) can overcome issues with heavy storage systems by lowering operating pressure down to 35-40 bar. Key to the success of adsorptive storage is the choice of suitable adsorbent and operating conditions. Porous carbonaceous materials are well known as one of the best adsorbents for gases. Preparation procedure of carbonaceous adsorbents for natural gas storage is described. Based on physicochemical parameters Polish hard coal type 34.1 from KWK Marcel was selected as precursor material for adsorbents for gas storage. Four grindings were performed on selected coal and particle size distribution was determined. Fullers distribution was calculated as providing best packing of precursor material. Comparison between optimal and obtained distributions allowed to select the best way of grinding coal providing best packing of precursor material. Thermo prepared coal tar and phenol-formaldehyde resol type resin were selected as binders, thermoreological study of binders and coal-binder mixtures were performed. Granules and pastilles from coal-binders mixtures were prepared and pyrolysed. Influence of binder amount in mixtures on mechanical resistance of granules were studied. Influence of steam activation time of granules on sorption parameters (Iodine number) of obtained active carbon monoliths was studied. High pressure adsorption of methane and low pressure adsorption of nitrogen was performed on selected samples of obtained active carbons monoliths.
Index Keywords: Adsorbed natural gas; Carbonaceous materials; Compressed natural gasses (CNG); High pressure adsorptions; Mechanical resistance; Physicochemical parameters; Preparation procedures; Volumetric energy densities; Automotive fuels; Carbonaceous adsorbents; Coal; Gas adsorption; Gasoline; Granulation; Grinding (machining); Methane; Mixtures; Natural gas; Particle size analysis; Storage (materials); Binders

Authors: Van Benthum R.J., Van Kemenade H.P., Brouwers J.J.H., Golombok M.
Title: CO2 capture by condensed rotational separation
Source title: 27th Annual International Pittsburgh Coal Conference 2010, PCC 2010
Affiliations: Eindhoven University of Technology, Netherlands
Authors with affiliations: Van Benthum, R.J., Eindhoven University of Technology, Netherlands; Van Kemenade, H.P., Eindhoven University of Technology, Netherlands; Brouwers, J.J.H., Eindhoven University of Technology, Netherlands; Golombok, M., Eindhoven University of Technology, Netherlands
Abstract: Condensed rotational separation is a technique in which flue gas is cleaned by condensation of the CO2 and mechanical centrifugal separation. It requires a purification of CO2 in the flue gas, prior to separation. This purification can be realized with existing techniques like oxygen enriched coal combustion or CO2 separating membranes. Combined with an enrichment technique, condensed rotational separation provides an answer that can compete with promising conventional techniques for CO2 capture, like oxy-fuel combustion or amine absorption. These conventional techniques produce a waste stream with a high CO2 purity that can be compressed to supercritical pressure for transport and storage. It is shown that energy consumption of CRS is only slightly more than gas compression of a sequestration stream resulting from conventional separation techniques.
Index Keywords: Centrifugal separation; Condensed rotational separations; Conventional techniques; Enrichment techniques; Gas compression; Oxyfuel combustion; Separation techniques; Super-critical pressures; Centrifugation; Coal combustion; Energy utilization; Flue gases; Fuels; Purification; Carbon dioxide

Authors: Abakhshin P.S., Vorotnitski V.E., Egorov M.V., Kalinkina M.A., Makoklyuev B.I., Polizharov A.S., Protopopova T.N., Turkina O.V.
Title: Methods and software tools for evaluation, forecasting and analysis of electric power and energy balances in electric power companies of Russia
Source title: 43rd International Conference on Large High Voltage Electric Systems 2010, CIGRE 2010
Affiliations: JSC R and D Centre for Power Engineering, Russian Federation
Authors with affiliations: Abakhshin, P.S., JSC R and D Centre for Power Engineering, Russian Federation; Vorotnitski, V.E., JSC R and D Centre for Power Engineering, Russian Federation; Egorov, M.V., JSC R and D Centre for Power Engineering, Russian Federation; Kalinkina, M.A., JSC R and D Centre for Power Engineering, Russian Federation; Makoklyuev, B.I., JSC R and D Centre for Power Engineering, Russian Federation; Polizharov, A.S., JSC R and D Centre for Power Engineering, Russian Federation; Protopopova, T.N., JSC R and D Centre for Power Engineering, Russian Federation; Turkina, O.V., JSC R and D Centre for Power Engineering, Russian Federation
Abstract: Balances of generation, transmission, distribution and consumption of electric power are the basis of power plants regimes planning, energy resource storage planning, equipment maintenance planning etc. Electricity transmission rates are set using aggregate expected balances of electric power. Three main groups of methods and software tools are being observed in this contribution: 1. For evaluation of electric power balances; factual (reported), technical and non-technical losses of electric power in transmission power lines of 220 kV and above and in distribution power lines of 0.4 - 110 kV with respect to regimes of this type of lines. 2. For prediction of electric power consumption, generation and power flow. 3. For optimization of long-term power energy regimes and planning of balances of electric power and energy. Methods and software tools observed in this contribution have been tested in some power companies of Russia in a comprehensive way. They have proved to be practically useful for solving wide area of maintenance, economical and dispatcher tasks.
Author Keywords: Electric power grid; Factual losses; Forecasting; Power; Power energy balance; Technical losses
Index Keywords: Electric power company; Electric power consumption; Electric power grids; Electricity transmission; Equipment maintenance; Power; Power energy; Technical loss; Computer software; Electric energy storage; Electric lines; Electric power transmission; Electric utilities; Energy balance; Energy resources; Forecasting; Electricity

Authors: Adamek F.J.
Title: Optimal storage location and layout in power supply systems
Source title: 43rd International Conference on Large High Voltage Electric Systems 2010, CIGRE 2010
Affiliations: High Voltage Laboratory, ETH Zürich, Switzerland
Authors with affiliations: Adamek, F.J., High Voltage Laboratory, ETH Zürich, Switzerland
Abstract: Use of renewable energy increased significantly during last years. Especially the intermittent sources of wind and photovoltaic are expected to increase further within the near future. Production and consumption of these intermittent energy sources do not coincide. Hence energy storages are needed to overcome periods of mismatch. To the operator of a power supply system the location, kind, capacity and type of these storages are important questions. They are discussed in this paper, determining the optimal position and size of storage within a given scenario. Optimality is defined by minimum CO2 emissions. The developed approach compares centralized and decentralized approaches of power generation of a larger region. The location of the storage and the renewable energy plants is varied within these systems. Here, an exemplary Swiss region is examined, consisting of a main city and several surrounding villages. Heat and electricity are supplied by various generation technologies processing different energy carriers. Conventional and renewable production are both available, and have to be coordinated to meet the demand. The energy supply infrastructure is assessed by a multiple-level model. It structures the region according to its settlement units. The resulting model consists of several superimposed levels, starting from small and going up to large settlement units. Each level comprises energy generation technologies and storages - if present - to supply the load. The plants of each level are aggregated in one energy hub, a unit that allows the conversion and storage of multiple energy carriers. The hubs are sorted hierarchically according to the multiple-level structure of the region, thus allowing the comparison of different locations and sizes of storages within the considered region. The aim is to determine the power supply strategy for the examined agglomeration with the smallest amount of emissions possible. Different storage positions are evaluated for a given scenario, i.e. a given set of generation units, regarding their emissions saving potential. Also, the renewable share and grid electricity mix are varied to evaluate preferable storage locations. The simulations showed that storage taps its full potential best in combined heat and power production situations, and that the power generation structure remarkably influences the benefits that can be drawn from storage use. Consequently the supply infrastructure has to be analyzed carefully in order to determine the optimal storage location within the system.
Author Keywords: Energy hub; Mulitple-level model; Optimization; Power supply; Renewables; Storage
Index Keywords: Combined heat and power production; Energy hubs; Generation technologies; Intermittent energy source; Power supply; Production and consumption; Renewables; Use of renewable energies; Carbon dioxide; Electric power generation; Electricity; Energy storage; Optimization; Renewable energy resources; Electric power systems

Authors: Dyachenko V.V., Chernyshev F.V., Chugunov I.N., Gin D.B., Gusev V.K., Khitrov S.A., Kurskiev G.S., Larionov M.M., Patrov M.I., Petrov Yu.V., Rozhdestvenskii V.V., Sakharov N.V., Shcherbinin O.N., Shevelev A.E., Stepanov. A.Yu., Tolstyakov. S.Yu.
Title: Non-inductive plasma current start-up and drive by RF power in the globus-M spherical tokamak
Source title: 37th EPS Conference on Plasma Physics 2010, EPS 2010
Affiliations: A.F.Ioffe Physico-Technical Institute, St.Petersburg, Russian Federation
Authors with affiliations: Dyachenko, V.V., A.F.Ioffe Physico-Technical Institute, St.Petersburg, Russian Federation; Chernyshev, F.V., A.F.Ioffe Physico-Technical Institute, St.Petersburg, Russian Federation; Chugunov, I.N., A.F.Ioffe Physico-Technical Institute, St.Petersburg, Russian Federation; Gin, D.B., A.F.Ioffe Physico-Technical Institute, St.Petersburg, Russian Federation; Gusev, V.K., A.F.Ioffe Physico-Technical Institute, St.Petersburg, Russian Federation; Khitrov, S.A., A.F.Ioffe Physico-Technical Institute, St.Petersburg, Russian Federation; Kurskiev, G.S., A.F.Ioffe Physico-Technical Institute, St.Petersburg, Russian Federation; Larionov, M.M., A.F.Ioffe Physico-Technical Institute, St.Petersburg, Russian Federation; Patrov, M.I., A.F.Ioffe Physico-Technical Institute, St.Petersburg, Russian Federation; Petrov, Yu.V., A.F.Ioffe Physico-Technical Institute, St.Petersburg, Russian Federation; Rozhdestvenskii, V.V., A.F.Ioffe Physico-Technical Institute, St.Petersburg, Russian Federation; Sakharov, N.V., A.F.Ioffe Physico-Technical Institute, St.Petersburg, Russian Federation; Shcherbinin, O.N., A.F.Ioffe Physico-Technical Institute, St.Petersburg, Russian Federation; Shevelev, A.E., A.F.Ioffe Physico-Technical Institute, St.Petersburg, Russian Federation; Stepanov., A.Yu., A.F.Ioffe Physico-Technical Institute, St.Petersburg, Russian Federation; Tolstyakov., S.Yu., A.F.Ioffe Physico-Technical Institute, St.Petersburg, Russian Federation
Abstract: Plasma start-up and current ramp-up without the central solenoid is an important problem on the way to compact fusion reactors. There are several experiments demonstrating such possibility due to absorption of electromagnetic waves in vicinity of the electron cyclotron resonance for plasma formation and then current start-up [1, 2, 3]. In our case the non-resonant scenario of plasma and current generation by RF power at 900 MHz frequency was used in toroidal vessel at standard toroidal and weak poloidal magnetic fields. Plasma current up to 17 kA was achieved with average density (1-3)1018 m-3 and 10-20 eV electron temperature. Experimental data indicate that the plasma current could be determined by high energy "tail" in electron energy distribution function.
Index Keywords: Central solenoid; Current generation; Electron energy distribution functions; Experimental datum; GLOBUS-M spherical tokamak; Plasma formations; Poloidal magnetic field; Toroidal vessels; Digital storage; Electromagnetic waves; Plasmas

Authors: Defreyne P., Andries L.
Title: Editing on generic storage over IT networks
Source title: Society of Motion Picture and Television Engineers Annual Technical Conference and Exhibition 2010, SMPTE 2010
Affiliations: VRT-medialab, Gaston Crommenlaan 10 bus 101, B-9050 Gent-Ledeberg, Belgium; CandIT-media, Gaston Crommenlaan 8 bus 102, B-9050 Gent-Ledeberg, Belgium
Authors with affiliations: Defreyne, P., VRT-medialab, Gaston Crommenlaan 10 bus 101, B-9050 Gent-Ledeberg, Belgium; Andries, L., CandIT-media, Gaston Crommenlaan 8 bus 102, B-9050 Gent-Ledeberg, Belgium
Abstract: At present, broadcast companies are increasingly implementing and optimizing file-based workflows for standard and high definition media production. In this respect, the Flemish public broadcaster in Belgium, VRT, has built the Digital Media Factory (DMF) for news production and generic programs in 2007. The DMF is based on the concept of a centralized generic storage platform. Often media services require their own dedicated storage platform. This results in many file transfers over the network. Performance and cost efficiency could be improved if media services could be integrated with the central storage platform. This paper describes the integration for post production environments, also referred to as in-place editing. It will be shown that the design of the IT network will have a profound impact of the performance. Traditional best practices for IT network design are no longer valid. This paper presents new insights on designing reliable IT networks in high performance media environments.

Authors: Krishnaswami V., Viswanathan V.
Title: Exploring the potential of phase change memories as an alternative to DRAM technology
Source title: World Academy of Science, Engineering and Technology
Affiliations: Delft University of Technology, Netherlands
Authors with affiliations: Krishnaswami, V., Delft University of Technology, Netherlands; Viswanathan, V., Delft University of Technology, Netherlands
Abstract: Scalability poses a severe threat to the existing DRAM technology. The capacitors that are used for storing and sensing charge in DRAM are generally not scaled beyond 42nm. This is because; the capacitors must be sufficiently large for reliable sensing and charge storage mechanism. This leaves DRAM memory scaling in jeopardy, as charge sensing and storage mechanisms become extremely difficult. In this paper we provide an overview of the potential and the possibilities of using Phase Change Memory (PCM) as an alternative for the existing DRAM technology. The main challenges that we encounter in using PCM are, the limited endurance, high access latencies, and higher dynamic energy consumption than that of the conventional DRAM. We then provide an overview of various methods, which can be employed to overcome these drawbacks. Hybrid memories involving both PCM and DRAM can be used, to achieve good tradeoffs in access latency and storage density. We conclude by presenting, the results of these methods that makes PCM a potential replacement for the current DRAM technology.
Author Keywords: DRAM; Phase change memory
Index Keywords: Access latency; Charge sensing; Charge storage; DRAM memories; DRAM technology; Dynamic energy consumption; Hybrid memories; Storage densities; Storage mechanism; Capacitors; Phase change memory; Dynamic random access storage

Title: Design analyses applied to a hyperbaric wave energy converter
Source title: 11th International Symposium on Practical Design of Ships and Other Floating Structures, PRADS 2010
Affiliations: Subsea Technology Laboratory, COPPE/UFRJ, Ocean Engineering Department, Rio de Janeiro, Brazil
Authors with affiliations: Estefen, S.F., Subsea Technology Laboratory, COPPE/UFRJ, Ocean Engineering Department, Rio de Janeiro, Brazil; Castello, X., Subsea Technology Laboratory, COPPE/UFRJ, Ocean Engineering Department, Rio de Janeiro, Brazil; Lourenço, M.I., Subsea Technology Laboratory, COPPE/UFRJ, Ocean Engineering Department, Rio de Janeiro, Brazil; Rossetto, R.M., Subsea Technology Laboratory, COPPE/UFRJ, Ocean Engineering Department, Rio de Janeiro, Brazil
Abstract: The concept of an onshore hyperbaric wave energy device for electricity generation from ocean waves is based on high pressure storage of water pumped by the motion of fl oaters. The device is composed of three different sub-systems working together: fl oaters/ pumps, high pressure water storage in the accumulator/ hyperbaric chamber and a turbine/generator. Following experimental tests in an ocean basin, a full scale prototype was designed in order to demonstrate the proposed concept given the environmental conditions at the installation site. Numerical analyses were performed in order to establish material requirements and geometric properties for the various components under both static and dynamic load conditions. Structural design provided the necessary data for detailed drawings to for the fabrication of components. © 2010 COPPE/UFRJ.

Title: Gas storage versus gas circulation in north atlantic and gondwana coal types
Source title: International Journal of Energy for a Clean Environment
Affiliations: Universidade Fernando Pessoa, CIAGEB, Praça de 9 de Abril 349, 4249-004 Porto, Portugal; Academia das Ciências de Lisboa, Rua da Academia das Ciências 19, 1249-122 Lisboa, Portugal
Authors with affiliations: Dinis, M.A.P., Universidade Fernando Pessoa, CIAGEB, Praça de 9 de Abril 349, 4249-004 Porto, Portugal; Rodrigues, C.F., Universidade Fernando Pessoa, CIAGEB, Praça de 9 de Abril 349, 4249-004 Porto, Portugal; Lemos De Sousa, M.J., Universidade Fernando Pessoa, CIAGEB, Praça de 9 de Abril 349, 4249-004 Porto, Portugal, Academia das Ciências de Lisboa, Rua da Academia das Ciências 19, 1249-122 Lisboa, Portugal
Abstract: The growing insufficiency in oil and natural gas supplies and the rise in energy consumption all over the world have created new opportunities to develop other energy products and technologies. Coal again acquired an important role in the global energy survey. International organizations are now conscious and resolved to systematically move into clean/cleaner coal technologies (CCTs) and, above all, into zero (or near zero) emission technologies (ZETs). Carbon capture and storage (CCS) technologies, acting in a complementary way to CCTs, are becoming one of the solutions to facing climate changes, permitting us not to avoid entirely but to minimize the green house gas effect (GHGE) to an acceptable level. It is also imperative to emphasize the actual crucial role of coal as a natural gas source rock and as a reservoir. Yet it is also important to understand that when coal has a high gas generation potential it does not necessarily imply that coal also has a high gas storage capacity and a high gas circulation performance. This investigation aims to compare the gas storage capacity and the gas circulation behavior between Gondwana and North Atlantic coal types. Two sets of Gondwana and North Atlantic coal types, with different ranks, were selected in the present research. Results revealed that the two sets of samples corresponded to different facies and, consequently, have different chemical and physical properties and quite different gas storage and gas circulation behaviors. In general terms, "North Atlantic-type" coals have a higher CH4 storage capacity than "Gondwana-type" coals due to differences in their petrographic characteristics, mainly in terms of vitrinite content and rank but also, although in a smaller scale, in terms of gas sorption temperatures. Diffusion coefficient values present a higher dependency on temperature changes than on gas storage capacities due to the high activation energy induced by high temperatures. © 2010 by Begell House, Inc.
Author Keywords: Gas circulation; Gas storage; Gondwana-type coal; North Atlantic-type coal; Petrography
Index Keywords: Carbon capture and storage; Coal technologies; Coal types; Emission technology; Energy products; Gas circulation; Gas generation; Gas Sorption; Gas storage; Gas storage capacity; Global energy; High activation energy; High temperature; International organizations; Natural gas sources; North Atlantic; Petrographic characteristics; Storage capacity; Temperature changes; Vitrinites; Carbon capture; Climate change; Diffusion; Energy utilization; Gas supply; Greenhouse gases; Oceanography; Petrography; Sorption; Technology; Coal; activation energy; carbon sequestration; cleaner production; climate change; coal; diffusion; energy use; gas flow; gas storage; Gondwana; greenhouse effect; high temperature; international organization; methane; natural gas; petrography; physicochemical property; sorption; source rock; vitrinite

Authors: Konstas K.D., Penvoteris Y.G., Caralis G.
Title: Maximization of wind energy penetration in Greek small islands with isolated power systems: Test case in Serifos
Source title: European Wind Energy Conference and Exhibition 2010, EWEC 2010
Affiliations: Flow - Wind Energy Consulting, Greece; National Technical University of Athens, Greece
Authors with affiliations: Konstas, K.D., Flow - Wind Energy Consulting, Greece; Penvoteris, Y.G., Flow - Wind Energy Consulting, Greece; Caralis, G., National Technical University of Athens, Greece
Abstract: In this paper, the maximization of wind energy penetration in non-interconnected Greek island power systems is investigated. Wind power systems, without examining cases of storage systems which seem difficult to be accomplished, are introduced in the islands under consideration with the following goals absolute satisfaction of electrical energy demand and peak load until 2020, minimization of the electricity production and environmental cost (see CO2 emissions), as well as safety of local electrical grid The achievement of above mentioned targets is investigated through the case of the island of Serifos Serifos is a small, non-interconnected island, located in the Aegean Sea where, nevertheless the wind potential is excellent, the wind power has a low degree of penetration. Taking into consideration the existing thermal and wind power plants of the island, the technical and dynamic limitations of function of thermal plants, real data of electricity demand and peak load, the predicted progress of electricity demand and peak load until 2020. and the evaluated capacity factor of the future wind power systems, different scenarios of wind energy penetration are anafysed.
Index Keywords: Aegean sea; Capacity factors; CO2 emissions; Electrical energy demand; Electrical grids; Electricity demands; Electricity production; Environmental costs; Isolated power system; Low degree; Peak load; Small island; Storage systems; Test case; Thermal plants; Wind potential; Carbon dioxide; Electric power system protection; Electric power transmission networks; Exhibitions; Wind power

Authors: Papastamoulos K., Vrettos E., Papathanassiou S., Boulaxis N.
Title: Introduction of battery energy storage in a small island grid to increase wind energy penetration levels
Source title: European Wind Energy Conference and Exhibition 2010, EWEC 2010
Affiliations: School of Electrical and Computer Engineering, National Technical University, Athens, Greece; Regulatory Authority for Energy, Athens, Greece
Authors with affiliations: Papastamoulos, K., School of Electrical and Computer Engineering, National Technical University, Athens, Greece, Regulatory Authority for Energy, Athens, Greece; Vrettos, E., School of Electrical and Computer Engineering, National Technical University, Athens, Greece; Papathanassiou, S., School of Electrical and Computer Engineering, National Technical University, Athens, Greece; Boulaxis, N., Regulatory Authority for Energy, Athens, Greece
Abstract: In small autonomous island systems, such as those in the Aegean Sea, Greece, the load is covered by diesel engines. Technical constraints of the conventional generating units keep RES penetration in these islands at low levels. To overcome such limitations, in the case of small island systems (peak power less than 1 MW) battery energy storage appears today as an attractive solution from a technical, economic and operational point of view. In the paper, the operation of a hybrid power station that consists of a Wind Turbine and Lead Acid batteries is simulated on an annual basis, using a steady-state "logistic" model, which accounts for the energy transactions between its various components, ignoring all electrical transients. Battery operation is modeled by the Hybrid2 model, which describes the operation of lead-acid accumulators during charge and discharge cycles, estimating also their expected lifetime. Moreover, the ideal size of the hybrid station is investigated considering the RES penetration and the economic feasibility of such a project. The results of the simulations indicate that a wind penetration levels up to 80% may be feasible.
Index Keywords: Aegean sea; Attractive solutions; Autonomous islands; Battery energy storage; Battery operation; Charge and discharge; Economic feasibilities; Electrical transients; Expected lifetime; Generating unit; Hybrid power stations; Low level; Peak power; Penetration level; Small island; Technical constraints; Wind penetration levels; Computer simulation; Diesel engines; Electric power transmission networks; Energy storage; Exhibitions; Lead acid batteries; Power quality; Wind power

Authors: Nielsen T.K., Olimstad G.
Title: Dynamic behaviour of reversible pump-turbines in turbine mode of operation
Source title: 13th International Symposium on Transport Phenomena and Dynamics of Rotating Machinery 2010, ISROMAC-13
Affiliations: Waterpower Laboratory, Department of Energy and Process Engineering, Norwegian University of Science and Technology, Alfred Getz vei 4, 7491 Trondheim, Norway
Authors with affiliations: Nielsen, T.K., Waterpower Laboratory, Department of Energy and Process Engineering, Norwegian University of Science and Technology, Alfred Getz vei 4, 7491 Trondheim, Norway; Olimstad, G., Waterpower Laboratory, Department of Energy and Process Engineering, Norwegian University of Science and Technology, Alfred Getz vei 4, 7491 Trondheim, Norway
Abstract: A reversible pump turbine is a machine that can operate in three modes of operation i.e. in pumping mode, in turbine mode and in phase compensating mode (idle speed). Reversible pump turbines (RPTs) have an increasing importance for regulation purposes for obtaining power balance in electric power systems. Especially in grids dominated by thermal energy, reversible pump turbines improve the overall governor stability. Increased use of new renewables (wind, wave and tidal power plants) will utterly demand better regulation ability of the more traditional power suppliers, enhancing the need for reversible pump turbines. It is, however, a necessity that both machine and system is designed for maximum flexibility in changing modes of operation from pump to turbine and vice versa. A reversible pump turbine is known for having very steep speed-flow characteristics which might give stability problems. During the design process, focus on the system dynamics in such power plants is essential. Simulation of the dynamic behaviour of the system implies a good representation of the turbine by its characteristics. It is necessary to be able to represent the characteristics before any measurements of the actual machine are available. This paper presents an possible explanation of the reason for these steep characteristics. Based on this hypothesis, a representation of the turbine for system dynamic simulation purposes is suggested.
Index Keywords: Better regulation; Compensating mode; Design process; Dynamic behaviours; Idle speed; In-phase; Modes of operation; Power balance; Power suppliers; Pump-turbines; Pumping modes; Renewables; Reversible pump-turbine; Stability problem; System Dynamics; Turbine modes; Computer simulation; Electric power systems; Pumped storage power plants; Rotating machinery; Tidal power plants; Transport properties; Hydraulic turbines
